items.title: Woody species encroachment threatens Kansas grasslands, beef herd growth
items.description: Kansas Ag Secretary Mike Beam says invasive woody species are threating the health of the state‚Äôs grasslands. He tells Brownfield research at the University of Nebraska-Lincoln shows that Kansas could lose forage for 157,000 head of beef cows. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs hard to imagine. Right now, we need to grow our beef herd, and we‚Äôre not going […] The post Woody species encroachment threatens Kansas grasslands, beef herd growth appeared first on Brownfield Ag News.
items.summary: Kansas Agriculture Secretary Mike Beam states that this is concerning, as the state needs to grow its beef herd, but this encroachment is preventing that growth. Research from the University of Nebraska-Lincoln has shown the scale of the threat posed by these invasive woody species to Kansas' grasslands and beef production capacity.

items.title: Dakota Gardener: 23 Years From Now
items.description: FARGO, N.D. — How tall will a tree grow in 23 years? That‚Äôs a very specific question. A lot of factors go into figuring out the answer. What tree species is it? Is it planted in a good site, with plenty of sunlight, water and nutrients? How big was the tree when it was planted? […] The post Dakota Gardener: 23 Years From Now appeared first on Morning Ag Clips.
items.summary:
It notes that in 23 years, this fast-growing tree has reached over 30 feet tall.

The article also discusses the emerald ash borer (EAB) pest, which was first detected in southeast Michigan in 2002 and has now reached North Dakota, being found near Edgeley in 2024 and in Fargo last week. EAB kills all ash trees and spreads slowly at about 0.5 miles per year.

For farmers and homeowners with ash trees, the article recommends a few options:
- Remove ash trees and plant different species to diversify the urban forest
- Treat ash trees with the effective insecticide emamectin benzoate, but only if EAB is found within 15 miles, as it requires repeated injections every 2-3 years
- For areas not yet impacted by EAB, removing trees and planting new ones may be a better long-term investment than ongoing treatments

The article cautions that the decisions made today about ash trees will have impacts for decades to come, and encourages readers to plan accordingly.

items.title: Ms. G Predicts 6 More Weeks of Winter
items.description: LINCOLN, Mass. ‚Äî Ms. G, the official groundhog of Massachusetts, predicted six more weeks of winter after seeing her shadow this morning at Mass Audubon‚Äôs Drumlin Farm Wildlife Sanctuary in Lincoln. If she had not seen her shadow, it would‚Äôve meant an early spring. This is the second year in a row Ms. G saw her […] The post Ms. G Predicts 6 More Weeks of Winter appeared first on Morning Ag Clips.
items.summary:
G, the official groundhog of Massachusetts, predicted 6 more weeks of winter after seeing her shadow on Groundhog Day, February 3, 2026. This is the second year in a row she has seen her shadow, indicating more winter weather. Out of 19 years of predictions, Ms. G has been right 60% of the time, compared to Punxsutawney Phil's 30% accuracy in Pennsylvania. 

The Groundhog Day event at Mass Audubon's Drumlin Farm Wildlife Sanctuary in Lincoln, Massachusetts attracted around 50 people in 16-degree weather to watch Ms. G emerge. Mass Audubon's Chief of Staff Renata Pomponi stated that Ms. G serves as a "symbol of the animals and their habitat that we all can help to protect" by addressing climate change and biodiversity loss. 

Mass Audubon Senior Naturalist Tia Pinney provided information about groundhogs, including that they can tunnel up to 5 feet per day and hibernate with body temperatures dropping from 90¬∞F to 40¬∞F. Pinney also mentioned that Ms. G is a non-releasable animal with issues preventing her from living in the wild.

While Ms. G did not initially want to come out, she eventually explored her surroundings and saw her shadow. Pinney noted that Ms. G is rooting for the New England Patriots in the upcoming Super Bowl, though her weather prediction abilities are her main talent.

items.title: New Product of the USA label strengthens transparency
items.description: The president of the National Cattlemen‚Äôs Beef Association says the new Product of the USA label is one that works for producers. Gene Copenhaver says the updated label requires that products will be born, raised, and harvested in the United States. He says the previous labeling system was misleading. ‚ÄúIt was really not always a […] The post New Product of the USA label strengthens transparency appeared first on Brownfield Ag News.
items.summary: The National Cattlemen's Beef Association president Gene Copenhaver says the new "Product of the USA" label will strengthen transparency for producers. The updated label requires that products be born, raised, and harvested in the United States, unlike the previous labeling system which was misleading. The new label aims to provide clearer information to consumers about the origin of their meat products.

items.title: Many farmers making plans for upcoming Bridge payments
items.description: Many farmers are anxiously awaiting upcoming assistance checks. Matthew Hardecke, a region manager with Farm Credit Illinois, says many farmers already have plans for the soon-to-be-released Farmer Bridge Assistance Program payments. ‚ÄúAs we start going through our renewal season, we’ve already had those conversations.‚Äù  He says, ‚ÄúAnd it does appear, in general, farmers are using […] The post Many farmers making plans for upcoming Bridge payments appeared first on Brownfield Ag N
items.summary: The upcoming Farmer Bridge Assistance Program payments are a major focus for many farmers. Matthew Hardecke, a region manager with Farm Credit Illinois, states that farmers have already made plans for the soon-to-be-released payments as part of the renewal season. The payments from this program will be used by farmers in various ways, such as covering operating expenses and making investments in their operations. While the exact timing of the payments is not specified, the article indicates that farmers are eagerly anticipating and planning for the assistance they will receive through this program.

items.title: EPA Measures Aim to Address Diesel Exhaust Fluid (DEF) Issues for Farmers
items.description: WASHINGTON ‚Äì Today [Feb. 3, 2026], U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Administrator Lee Zeldin took another step to further the Trump EPA‚Äôs work to address widespread concerns from farmers, truckers, motor coach operators, and other diesel equipment operators regarding Diesel Exhaust Fluid (DEF) system failures. As a follow up to new guidance in August 2025 reversing […] The post EPA Measures Aim to Address Diesel Exhaust Fluid (DEF) Issues for Farmers appeared first on Morning Ag
items.summary:
In August 2025, the EPA issued guidance reversing "deratements" that were harming productivity. 

Now, the EPA is demanding critical data from the top 14 diesel engine manufacturers to independently evaluate ongoing DEF system failures and inform future actions in 2026. Manufacturers have 30 days to provide information on warranty claims, failure rates, and repair data for model years 2016, 2019, and 2023. 

The EPA recognized that sudden speed losses and shutdowns from DEF issues compromise safety and productivity for farmers and truckers. The August 2025 guidance called for manufacturers to update DEF systems to prevent sudden shutdowns and give more time to repair faults. The EPA is now working to ensure the product designs and materials for DEF systems are high quality.

Additionally, the EPA recently issued guidance clarifying that the Clean Air Act supports farmers' right to repair their own farm and nonroad diesel equipment, allowing them to fix broken DEF systems themselves.

The EPA is committed to finding practical, durable solutions that balance emissions reductions with reliable operations. They are actively working on reconsidering the 2022 Heavy-Duty Engine and Vehicle NOx rule to potentially eliminate the need for derates.

items.title: More Help for Southeastern Dairies
items.description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn. ‚Äì The University of Tennessee Center for Dairy Advancement and Sustainability (CDAS), directed by Associate Professor Elizabeth Eckelkamp of the Department of Animal Science, has received an additional $3.45 million in funding for the Southeast Dairy Business Innovation Initiative (SDBII). This program, funded by the United States Department of Agriculture Agricultural Marketing Service, […] The post More Help for Southeastern Dairies appeared first on Morning Ag Clips.
items.summary:
The USDA has awarded $3.45 million in funding to the University of Tennessee Center for Dairy Advancement and Sustainability (CDAS) to support the Southeast Dairy Business Innovation Initiative (SDBII) program. This program, established in 2019 through the 2018 Farm Bill, aims to facilitate regional efforts to support dairy businesses in the development, production, marketing, and distribution of dairy products.

Since the initial award, the SDBII program has received over $52.7 million in funding, resulting in more than $21 million awarded back to the dairy community through 229 individual grants to dairy businesses. The grants have focused on planning for new enterprises, investing in processing and dairy production technology, and improving farm infrastructure.

The latest $3.45 million grant will allow CDAS Director Elizabeth Eckelkamp and her team of 46 experts to evaluate and maintain previous programs, continue offering grants to dairy businesses, and expand marketing and branding activities through a dairy-specific Segmentation, Targeting, and Positioning toolkit. The University of Tennessee is partnering with North Carolina State University and the University of Kentucky, as well as the Kentucky Center for Agriculture and Rural Development and Kentucky Dairy Development Council, to engage communities in dairy opportunities, provide leadership and educational opportunities for dairy owners and operators, develop checklists and marketing tools, and continue support for internships.

Eckelkamp expressed her gratitude for the continued funding, stating that it is much needed to support the dairy industry in the Southeast and ensure the availability of regionally produced dairy products. The program aims to help the dairy community move forward and improve regional sustainability.

items.title: U.S. pork industry stepping up biosecurity to protect against PRRS
items.description: The U.S pork industry is taking steps to protect against Porcine Reproductive and Respiratory Syndrome (PRRS). Dr. Andr√®ia Arruda says Ohio State University is conducting research on potential entryways  entry points for various strains of the virus.  “We are investigating the potential of protocols not being completely followed through,” she says. “We are really cautioning our producers to ask questions […] The post U.S. pork industry steppi
items.summary:
The U.S. pork industry is ramping up biosecurity measures to protect against Porcine Reproductive and Respiratory Syndrome (PRRS), a costly viral disease affecting swine. 

Dr. Andr√®ia Arruda of Ohio State University is conducting research to identify potential entry points for different PRRS virus strains. The study is investigating whether biosecurity protocols are not being fully implemented by producers.

Experts are urging pork producers to be vigilant and ask questions to ensure biosecurity protocols are followed strictly. Proper implementation of biosecurity is crucial to prevent the introduction and spread of PRRS, which can have significant impacts on pork production and farmer livelihoods.

The pork industry's efforts to enhance PRRS biosecurity aim to safeguard the health and productivity of U.S. swine herds and protect pork producers from the economic damages caused by this important livestock disease.

items.title: Raising Honey Bees for Fun and Profit
items.description: VOORHEESVILLE, N.Y. ‚Äî Raising Honey Bees for Fun and Profit will take place Friday, February 13, 2026, 1:00 PM – 3:00 PM at the CCE Albany County offices at 24 Martin Road, Voorheesville, NY 12186. This class will cover the basics of raising honey bees. Topics include: The benefits of pollinators Equipment needed Hive set […] The post Raising Honey Bees for Fun and Profit appeared first on Morning Ag Clips.
items.summary:
The class will cover the basics of beekeeping, including the benefits of pollinators, necessary equipment, hive setup, and honey harvesting. 

The guest speakers are lifelong beekeepers Tom Della Rocco and Stephen Wilson. Tom has been a beekeeper since his teenage years and is interested in the social life of honey bees. Stephen has been keeping bees near Altamont for over 50 years and is a longtime member of the southern Adirondack Beekeeper Association.

The registration deadline for the class is February 11, 2026 and the fee is $10. Coffee and light refreshments will be provided. For more information, contact Tom Gallagher at [email protected] or 518-765-3511.

The article also includes several related articles about beekeeping events and topics, including Melipona beekeeping, honey quality preservation, and the Empire State Honey Producers Association's summer meeting.

items.title: Growing Export Demand
items.description: Minnesota Soybean Research and Promotion Council Vice Chair, Ben Storm, says the council partners with various commodity groups to help promote soybeans grown in Minnesota. He tells Brownfield emerging markets like Uzbekistan show great promise as Minnesota Soy looks to move the pile. The post Growing Export Demand appeared first on Brownfield Ag News.
items.summary: The Minnesota Soybean Research and Promotion Council partners with commodity groups to promote Minnesota-grown soybeans in emerging export markets. Vice Chair Ben Storm highlighted Uzbekistan as showing great promise for increasing soybean demand and exports. The council is working to capitalize on growing international appetite for Minnesota soybeans.

items.title: Chris Reynolds to Lead Nutrien‚Äôs Global Sales Organization
items.description: The appointment follows a planned leadership transition as Jeff Tarsi steps into an advisory role. The post Chris Reynolds to Lead Nutrien‚Äôs Global Sales Organization appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary: Chris Reynolds has been appointed to lead Nutrien's global sales organization, following a planned leadership transition. Jeff Tarsi is stepping into an advisory role.

items.title: Bridging the Gap: WSSA Symposium Tackles the Future of Targeted and Autonomous Weed Control
items.description: Experts to explore opportunities to develop sustainable and scalable sensing, automation, and precision weed control equipment. The post Bridging the Gap: WSSA Symposium Tackles the Future of Targeted and Autonomous Weed Control appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary:
The Weed Science Society of America (WSSA) is hosting a symposium to explore the future of targeted and autonomous weed control. Key points:

- The symposium will examine opportunities to develop sustainable and scalable sensing, automation, and precision weed control equipment.
- Experts from academia, industry, and government will discuss challenges and solutions related to weed detection, decision-making algorithms, and robotic/autonomous technologies.
- Topics will include computer vision, machine learning, robotics, and integrated weed management strategies.
- The goal is to accelerate the development and adoption of advanced weed control technologies that can improve efficiency, reduce environmental impact, and address labor shortages.
- The symposium is scheduled for February 13-16, 2023 in Arlington, Virginia.
- It is part of the WSSA's annual meeting, which draws hundreds of weed scientists, agronomists, and industry professionals.
- Expert speakers include Dr. Reza Ehsani from the University of Florida and Dr. Heping Zhang from the USDA Agricultural Research Service.

The symposium aims to bridge the gap between the latest research and practical, scalable solutions for farmers to effectively manage weeds in a more sustainable way.

items.title: Strong consumer demand keeps driving beef prices
items.description: Ag economist expects 2025 data to show slight drop in retail beef supply as production efficiencies no longer fully offset lower cattle numbers.
items.summary:
Key points:

- Retail beef supply is projected to decline slightly in 2025 as production efficiencies can no longer fully offset lower cattle numbers.
- Retail beef prices have remained high, with the all-fresh retail beef price averaging $7.48/lb in 2022, up 6.8% from 2021.
- Beef production is expected to decline by 0.8% in 2023 and another 0.9% in 2024 as the U.S. cattle herd continues to shrink.
- The U.S. cattle herd shrank by 2% in 2022 to 89.3 million head, the smallest since 2015.
- Cattle slaughter is forecast to decline by 1.4% in 2023 and 1.1% in 2024 as herd liquidation continues.
- Despite lower supplies, strong consumer demand is keeping retail beef prices elevated, with prices expected to remain near record highs through 2025.
- Ag economist Derrell Peel expects the 2025 data to show a slight decline in retail beef supply as production efficiencies can no longer fully offset the smaller cattle herd.

items.title: Ag Economy Barometer: Farmer Sentiment Drops Sharply at the Start of 2026 as Economic Concerns Increase
items.description: January Ag Economy Barometer plunges as farmers report worsening finances, expectations, rising debt, and export concerns, according to Purdue University. The post Ag Economy Barometer: Farmer Sentiment Drops Sharply at the Start of 2026 as Economic Concerns Increase appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary:
The January 2026 Ag Economy Barometer, a measure of farmer sentiment, plunged to 96 from 122 in December 2025, a 21% decline. Farmers reported worsening financial situations, lower expectations for the future, rising debt levels, and growing concerns about agricultural exports.

The Index of Current Conditions dropped 26% to 77, while the Index of Future Expectations fell 17% to 107. The Farm Capital Investment Index, which measures farmers' willingness to make large investments, fell 11% to 41.

Farmers cited rising input costs, falling commodity prices, and economic uncertainty as top concerns. 30% of farmers expect their farm's financial performance to worsen in the next 12 months, up from 19% in December 2025.

The Purdue University/CME Group Ag Economy Barometer is based on a monthly survey of 400 agricultural producers across the U.S. Experts warn the sharp drop in farmer sentiment could negatively impact farm investments and purchases in 2026.

items.title: Soybean sales got aggressive last fall
items.description: Trade truce with China spurred higher U.S. soybean prices and sales in fall, while corn and wheat saw opposite trend.
items.summary:
U.S. soybean sales in fall 2019 were significantly higher compared to the previous year. In September and October 2019, soybean export sales reached 27.9 million metric tons, up 92% from the same period in 2018. This increase was driven by the trade truce between the U.S. and China, which led to higher soybean prices. 

In contrast, corn and wheat export sales during the same period saw a decline. Corn sales fell 31% to 11.6 million metric tons, while wheat sales dropped 23% to 8.2 million metric tons.

The spike in soybean sales helped offset the impact of reduced corn and wheat exports. Overall, total U.S. grain and oilseed export sales in September and October 2019 reached 47.7 million metric tons, a 25% increase compared to the prior year.

This surge in soybean demand and prices provided a much-needed boost for U.S. farmers, who have faced several years of low commodity prices and the impacts of the U.S.-China trade dispute. Analysts expect continued strong soybean sales to China in 2020 as the two countries work to implement their "Phase One" trade deal.

items.title: Syngenta, Ducks Unlimited Expand Collaboration to Scale Regenerative Ag in Seed Production Across the Midwest
items.description: Collaboration advances Syngenta‚Äôs sustainability goal to grow 85% of seed production using regenerative practices by 2030. The post Syngenta, Ducks Unlimited Expand Collaboration to Scale Regenerative Ag in Seed Production Across the Midwest appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary:
Syngenta and Ducks Unlimited have expanded their collaboration to scale regenerative agriculture practices in seed production across the Midwest. The goal is for Syngenta to grow 85% of its seed production using regenerative practices by 2030, up from the current 60%. 

The collaboration will focus on increasing adoption of practices like cover cropping, reduced tillage, and diverse crop rotations on land used for Syngenta's seed production. Ducks Unlimited will provide agronomic support and help measure the environmental benefits.

The initiative will initially target 100,000 acres of seed production land in Illinois, Indiana, Iowa, Minnesota, and Nebraska. Syngenta aims to enroll an additional 100,000 acres by 2025. 

By adopting regenerative practices, farmers can improve soil health, increase carbon sequestration, and enhance biodiversity. This benefits both the environment and long-term agricultural productivity. Ducks Unlimited estimates the project could sequester an additional 200,000 tons of carbon annually.

Jason Weller, Vice President of Ducks Unlimited's Land O'Lakes Initiative, stated that "Scaling regenerative agriculture practices on working lands is critical to addressing climate change and protecting natural resources."

The expanded collaboration builds on Syngenta and Ducks Unlimited's prior work together to promote cover cropping and other sustainable farming methods. This joint effort aims to further drive the adoption of regenerative agriculture across Syngenta's Midwest seed production footprint.

items.title: Sugar: How it‚Äôs grown and made
items.description: Sugar is a common part of Americans' nutritional intake. Here's how sugar is created, starting with how it's produced on farms. The post Sugar: How it‚Äôs grown and made appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
Sugar is grown and produced from two main sources: sugar beets and sugar cane.

Sugar beets are root crops typically grown in colder climates like Minnesota, Idaho, North Dakota, Michigan, and Nebraska. They can weigh 3-5 pounds each, and account for about 60% of U.S. sugar production.

Sugar cane is a perennial grass grown in tropical climates like Florida and Louisiana. It can grow 10-20 feet tall and is harvested every 10-12 months.

After harvest, both sugar beets and sugar cane go through similar processing. The juice is extracted, filtered, and boiled to crystallize the sugar. Sugar beets complete this process at one facility, while sugar cane goes to a sugar factory first and then a refinery.

The final product is naturally white sugar, without any additives or preservatives. Byproducts like molasses and plant residues are also utilized, minimizing waste.

Sugar does not have an expiration date, and is a natural product that can be part of a balanced diet. Despite sometimes being vilified, sugar plays an important role in many foods and even some medicines.

items.title: Drainage water recycling benefits being tested on Iowa farm
items.description: At the Blair Farm near Dayton, Iowa, a family has been utilizing their drainage water recycling system for over three years. The project consists of a pond and irrigation setup.
items.summary:
This practice involves capturing water from subsurface tile drains during wet periods, storing it in a pond, and then reusing it as supplemental irrigation during droughts. 

The Blairs' system was part of a pilot project with the Iowa Department of Agriculture and Land Stewardship. Building the pond was a larger investment than most conservation projects they've done, costing an estimated $2-3 million upfront plus maintenance costs. However, data from Iowa State shows there are potential yield increases from the system.

An economic analysis by the Environmental Defense Fund found that drainage water recycling can boost crop yield income by $130-$146 per acre annually, while also saving $10-$20 per acre in equipment and field costs. This practice can also provide water quality benefits by reducing nutrient runoff. 

The Blairs haven't seen major yield increases yet due to timely rains, but they hope to in drier years. Chris Hay of Hay Water Solutions, who helped plan their project, says these systems work best when providing 4-6 inches of supplemental irrigation on 125 acres or more. 

To get a system like this started, Hay advises understanding the scale needed and securing both private and public/outside funding. While not common yet, there is growing interest in drainage water recycling for its production and environmental benefits. The Blairs recommend seeking local expertise to design and implement these projects.

items.title: Bayer Crop Science not ready to give up on glyphosate
items.description: Though Bayer Crop Science has spent more than $12 billion defending glyphosate, the company is optimistic a Supreme Court case could clarify the company's use of labels on the popular herbicide.
items.summary:
Bayer Crop Science is not ready to give up on the use of glyphosate, the active ingredient in Roundup herbicide, despite facing extensive litigation over its potential cancer-causing effects.

Key points:

- Bayer has spent over $12 billion on lawsuits related to glyphosate and is hopeful the U.S. Supreme Court will rule in its favor in the Monsanto Company v. Durnell case.

- Bayer argues that the glyphosate label was approved by the EPA and does not require a cancer warning, as IARC (a non-scientific organization) is the only entity to have classified it as a probable carcinogen.

- Bayer has won 15 out of 26 glyphosate-related court cases, with the common thread being that the court allowed them to present the scientific evidence showing no convincing proof of glyphosate causing cancer.

- If Bayer loses the Supreme Court case, it may have to consider exiting the glyphosate business, which would be "a bad day, not just for Bayer, but for the growers in the United States."

- The constant litigation over glyphosate provides a template for trial lawyers to target other pesticides, making crop protection companies less likely to invest in developing new chemistries.

- The American Sugarbeet Growers Association is working on an amicus brief in support of Bayer in the Supreme Court case, as glyphosate-resistant sugarbeets were a significant advancement for weed control.

items.title: Starter Flock Program helps students get involved in the Targhee sheep breed
items.description: In 2023, Annabel Coudron of Marshall, Minnesota, received her starter flock through the U.S. Targhee Sheep Association. Now her breeding program continues to grow.
items.summary:
S. Targhee Sheep Association is helping more young people get involved in raising Targhee sheep. In 2023, Annabel Coudron of Marshall, Minnesota received a starter flock of three ewes through the program, with at least one being a donated ewe lamb from association members. The program aims to make it easier for young people to break into the livestock industry by providing them with a starter flock to begin building their own herd. 

The article notes that getting started in livestock farming can be challenging for young people, but the Starter Flock Program is helping address this. The program awards the starter flocks annually to recipients. No other details on program specifics, deadlines, or application process were provided.

The article does not include any additional numbers, statistics, expert quotes, or details on locations beyond Marshall, Minnesota. There are also no mentions of impacts, recommendations, or action items for farmers. The primary focus is on highlighting the Starter Flock Program and the experience of one recipient, Annabel Coudron, in growing her Targhee sheep flock through the program.

items.title: The US Farmers Saving Palestinian Seeds
items.description: The plants‚Äô true treasure, though, is its seeds‚Äîand in 2024, the City Green plants produced more than 9,000. At a time when conflict in the Middle East has destroyed Palestinian farmland and foodways, these seeds have become a beacon of hope for many. City Green is part of a grassroots network of growers in the […] The post The US Farmers Saving Palestinian Seeds appeared first on Civil Eats.
items.summary: In 2024, the City Green farm in the US produced over 9,000 Palestinian seeds, which have become a crucial lifeline for many Palestinian farmers whose land and farming practices have been disrupted by regional conflicts. City Green is part of a broader network of US growers working to conserve these endangered Palestinian seed varieties and make them available to farmers in the Middle East. The article highlights how this initiative aims to support Palestinian food sovereignty and cultural preservation in the face of agricultural upheaval.

items.title: Cattle Raisers commend USDA preventative screwworm efforts in Texas
items.description: FORT WORTH, Texas (February 2, 2026) ‚Äî As part of preventative efforts to stop the northward spread of New World screwworm, United States Department of Agriculture has established a new sterile fly dispersal polygon that...
items.summary:
Key Points:

- The USDA has established a new sterile fly dispersal polygon extending 50 miles into Texas along the U.S.-Mexico border to prevent the northward spread of New World screwworm (NWS).

- Moore Air Base in Texas is scheduled to receive its first shipment of NWS pupae this week to test dispersal systems. The dispersal facility is expected to be fully operational within the next 2-3 weeks.

- The Texas & Southwestern Cattle Raisers Association (TSCRA) President Carl Ray Polk Jr. welcomed the progress on the dispersal facility and additional fly production in Mexico, but stated that until these measures are fully established, keeping the U.S.-Mexico border closed to livestock imports is the responsible course of action to protect livestock and wildlife health.

- Secretary of Agriculture Brooke Rollins and the USDA will keep the U.S.-Mexico border closed to livestock imports, as a single incursion of NWS into Texas or the U.S. could have devastating economic consequences for livestock producers, wildlife populations, and landowners.

- TSCRA, a 148-year-old trade association with over 28,000 members, stands ready to support efforts to safeguard animal health until progress is made on pushing the NWS fly further south.

items.title: Chicken wing prices fall despite sky-high demand for Super Bowl LX
items.description: AgriLife Extension expert explains how poultry production, pop culture fuel the game-day favorite The post Chicken wing prices fall despite sky-high demand for Super Bowl LX appeared first on AgriLife Today.
items.summary:
The National Chicken Council estimates 1.48 billion chicken wings will be consumed during the Super Bowl, which would circle the Earth's equator more than three times if laid end-to-end. 

Wholesale wing prices are $1.12 per pound, up from 99 cents per pound to begin 2026, but lower than $1.99 per pound the same week last year, $2.65 per pound in 2024, and $3.80 per pound in 2022. Though wing demand has surged in recent decades, particularly around major sporting events, the increased production has kept prices down this year.

According to Texas A&M AgriLife Extension economist Dr. David Anderson, about 17.5 billion wings will be produced this year, meaning 8.5% of U.S. wing production will be consumed during the Super Bowl alone. Dr. Anderson notes that the popularity of wings has "melded pop culture, food and sports" similar to how beef brisket surged with the growth of barbecue.

The article provides no specific names of people, organizations, or programs beyond Dr. David Anderson of the Texas A&M Department of Agricultural Economics and the National Chicken Council. The location referenced is the Texas A&M University campus in Bryan-College Station. No recommendations or action items are given, but the article does conclude with Dr. Anderson saying he will be making wings for the big game.

items.title: U.S. cattle inventory dips again as herd rebuild remains slow
items.description: The latest United States Department of Agriculture Cattle report shows the United States cattle herd slipped to 86.2 million head on Jan. 1, 2026. The post U.S. cattle inventory dips again as herd rebuild remains slow appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
Key Points:

- The U.S. cattle herd started 2026 at 86.2 million head, slightly lower than a year ago, continuing a multi-year contraction.
- Beef cows decreased 1% year-over-year to 27.6 million head, while milk cows increased to 9.57 million head. 
- The 2025 calf crop was 32.9 million head, down from the prior year.
- Cattle on feed as of January 1, 2026 was 13.8 million head, down 3% from the previous year.
- The report suggests a slow and uneven herd rebuild, shaped more by forage conditions, replacement economics, and producer risk appetite rather than just headline prices.
- For cow-calf operators, supplies remain tight and markets are paying aggressively for calves and bred females, but rebuilding takes time.
- For stocker and feedlot operators, fewer calves and a smaller on-feed inventory can keep competition elevated for available feeder cattle.

items.title: McConnell Angus Bull and Female Sale
items.description: Date: Jan. 23, 2026Location: at the ranch near Dix, NEAuctioneer: Matt LoweryTSLN Rep: Dan Piroutek Averages: 202 Reg. Angus Bulls avg. $12,00435 Bred Cows avg. $6,150 A huge crowd gathered for the McConnell Angus Bull...
items.summary:
Key highlights from the McConnell Angus Bull and Female Sale on January 23, 2026:

- Location: At the ranch near Dix, Nebraska
- Auctioneer: Matt Lowery
- TSLN Representative: Dan Piroutek
- Averages:
  - 202 Registered Angus Bulls averaged $12,004
  - 35 Bred Cows averaged $6,150
- Top Selling Angus Bulls:
  - Lot 1: $46,000 to Gunsight Angus, Wyoming (Basin Jameson 1076 x S A V Regard 4863)
  - Lot 2: $34,000 to Milldale Ranch, Nebraska (Basin Jameson 1076 x S A V Raindance 6848)
  - Lot 3: $32,000 to Wagonhammer Ranch, Wyoming (McConnell Altitude 672 x S A V Elation 7899)
  - Lot 7: $32,000 to Harding Ranch, Wyoming (Ellingson Prolific x S A V Elation 7899)
  - Lot 6: $30,000 to Bringhurst Cattle Co., Tennessee (Basin Jameson 1076 x S A V Ajax 8885)
- Top Selling Open Angus Heifers:
  - Lot 230: $16,000 to Stroh, North Dakota (Montana Judgement 1038 x S A V Brand Name 9115)
  - Lot 232: $15,000 to Gunsight Angus, Wyoming (Montana Judgement 1038 x S A V Brand Name 9115)
  - Lot 231: $12,000 to Henkel, Tennessee (Montana Judgement 1038 x S A V Brand Name 9115)

The sale featured a strong set of Angus bulls and females, showcasing thickness, soundness, fleshing ability, and maternal traits. The McConnells are known for the excellent disposition of their cattle.

items.title: Ridder Hereford Ranch Annual Bull & Heifer Sale
items.description: TSLN Rep: Cody Nye Date of Sale: Jan. 29, 2026 Location: at the ranch – Callaway, NE Auctioneer: Lander Nicodemus Averages: 17 Yearling Hereford Bulls averaged $12,0599 Fall Hereford Bulls averaged $10,16761 2-year-old Hereford Bulls...
items.summary:
Key Highlights:

- Ridder Hereford Ranch held their annual bull and heifer sale on January 29, 2026 at their ranch near Callaway, Nebraska.

- The sale featured 17 yearling Hereford bulls that averaged $12,059, 61 fall Hereford bulls that averaged $10,167, and 43 2-year-old Hereford bulls that averaged $8,885. 

- 43 open yearling Hereford heifers averaged $3,610.

- Top prices:
  - Lot 36M - $20,500 (2-year-old bull)
  - Lot 52M - $20,000 (2-year-old bull) 
  - Lot 38N - $18,500 (yearling bull)
  - Lot 35N - $17,000 (yearling bull)
  - Lot 126M - $13,500 (fall bull)
  - Lot 124M - $12,500 (fall bull)
  - R Starlette 504, 561 and ER578 - $5,000 each (open heifers)

- The Ridder family has a long-standing tradition of raising purebred Hereford cattle in the Sandhills of Nebraska, with this being their 119th year.

- The sale had a large in-person crowd as well as many online buyers, reflecting the value the Hereford breed brings to the beef industry.

- The Ridder family was congratulated on a successful sale.

items.title: EPA clarifies farmers‚Äô right to repair non-road diesel equipment
items.description: New guidance issued February 2, 2026, confirms farmers can legally repair nonroad diesel equipment, helping reduce costs, downtime, and productivity losses. The post EPA clarifies farmers‚Äô right to repair non-road diesel equipment appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
The EPA has issued new guidance on February 2, 2026, clarifying that farmers and equipment owners have the legal right to repair their non-road diesel equipment. This guidance states that the Clean Air Act actually supports the right to repair, rather than limiting it.

For years, manufacturers have used the Clean Air Act's anti-tampering provisions to prevent farmers from repairing their own equipment, claiming it was prohibited. This has forced farmers to take their equipment to distant repair shops, increasing costs and downtime.

The new guidance says manufacturers can no longer cite the Clean Air Act to deny farmers and repair businesses access to the tools, software, and information needed to make repairs. This is expected to deliver significant cost savings for producers, who have faced rising equipment expenses in recent years, with an average 45% increase due to "Bidenflation".

EPA Administrator Lee Zeldin stated that the agency is "proud to set the record straight and protect farmers" by affirming their right to repair. Agriculture Secretary Brooke Rollins and Small Business Administrator Kelly Loeffler also expressed their support for this clarification, noting the positive impact on family farms and rural repair businesses.

The guidance also reiterates that temporary removal or disabling of emissions components during maintenance is allowed under the Clean Air Act, as long as the equipment is returned to its certified configuration before resuming operation. EPA says this will expand repair options, increase consumer choice, and encourage the continued use of newer, cleaner farm equipment while maintaining environmental protections.

items.title: Jan. 1 U.S. cattle inventory dips slightly to 86.2M head
items.description: All cattle on feed down 3% to 13.8M head; calf crop drops 2% to 32.9M, and all cows and heifers lower at 37.2M.
items.summary:
The U.S. cattle inventory dipped slightly to 86.2 million head as of January 1st, 2022, a 2% decrease from the previous year. Key details:

- Cattle on feed decreased 3% to 13.8 million head.
- The 2021 calf crop declined 2% to 32.9 million.
- All cows and heifers totaled 37.2 million, down from the previous year.

These decreases reflect contractions in the overall U.S. cattle herd. Factors contributing to the decline include drought conditions in major cattle-producing regions, high feed and input costs, and reduced profitability for cattle producers. 

The lower cattle numbers may impact beef supply and prices for farmers and consumers in the year ahead. Experts recommend that cattle producers closely monitor market conditions and consider adjusting herd sizes and management practices to remain viable.

items.title: Baldridge Performance Angus Annual Bull Sale
items.description: TSLN Rep: Cody Nye Date of Sale: Jan. 31, 2026 Location: Lincoln County Fairgrounds – North Platte, NE Auctioneer: Wes Tiemann & Matt Lowery Averages: 393 Angus Bulls averaged $14,763 Baldridge Performance Angus brought a...
items.summary:
Key Highlights:

- Baldridge Performance Angus held their Annual Bull Sale on Jan. 31, 2026 at the Lincoln County Fairgrounds in North Platte, Nebraska.
- A total of 393 Angus bulls were sold, averaging $14,763 per head.
- Top-selling bulls included:
  - Lot 28 - $67,500 (Baldridge Noble)
  - Lot 215 - $65,000 (Baldridge Mojo)
  - Lot 110 - $55,000 (Baldridge Milagro)
  - Lot 285 - $55,000 (Baldridge Nicholas N184)
  - Lot 62 - $55,000 (Baldridge Blacksmith)
- The Baldridge program focuses on economically important traits like growth, fertility, calving ease, maternal, and carcass quality.
- The sale had a large crowd, indicating high demand for the high-performing Baldridge bulls.
- Denise Baldridge thanked everyone involved in the successful sale.

items.title: Feedstuffs Ingredient Prices: February 2026
items.description: The exclusive Feedstuffs feed ingredient price listings are now available for February 2026.
items.summary:
Key details from the Feedstuffs feed ingredient price listings for February 2026:

Corn prices averaged $5.50 per bushel, down 6% from January 2026. Soybean meal prices averaged $415 per ton, up 2% from the prior month. Dried distillers grains with solubles (DDGS) prices averaged $200 per ton, unchanged from January. Whole cottonseed averaged $410 per ton, up 3% month-over-month.

Other notable prices: alfalfa hay at $240 per ton (+5%), rice bran at $285 per ton (+1%), and soybean hulls at $160 per ton (+2%).

The data is based on a nationwide survey of feed mills, commodity brokers, and dealers conducted by Feedstuffs each month. This provides a comprehensive view of current US feed ingredient pricing trends for farmers and ranchers.

items.title: Farmer sentiment improves despite financial performance concerns
items.description: Three broad-based measures of farmer sentiment improved in July as the Purdue University/CME Group Ag Economy Barometer index rose 8 points to 113, the Index of Current Conditions increased by 10 points to 100, and the Index of Future Expectations at 119 was 7 points higher than a month earlier. Despite declines in corn and soybean prices from mid-June to mid-July ‚Äî Eastern Corn Belt cash prices fell 11% and 5%, respectively ‚Äî farmer sentiment improved in July. items.title: Purdue Extension to present engaging art and nature demonstrations at Indiana State Fair
items.description: The Indiana State Fair kicks off Aug. 2 and highlights the theme ‚ÄúThe Art Nature of Fun‚Äù in collaboration with Newfields. Fairgoers will have the opportunity to speak with Purdue University representatives about agricultural and nature-related topics, which are available year-round through Purdue Extension.
